speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: This podcast series, Contextualizing Feminist Voices, is designed to provide background

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: information for people using the Global Feminism Project website. The podcast aims to provide

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: users with a well-informed perspective on interesting aspects of the interviews from

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: a particular country. For each episode, one of the project staff interviews an expert on that country site. Welcome to this episode of Contextualizing

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Feminist Voices. My name is Ozge Savas, and in this episode, I'm talking with my University

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: of Michigan colleague, Professor Liz Cole, who will provide a perspective on the interviews

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: from the United States. Because we have limited time, we will get right to the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: point. Liz, my first question is, what are one or two themes that come up in the interviews

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: that users should pay close attention to because those themes are particularly important in the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: United States women's movement, scholarship, or activism? Well, I think one theme that really came up across

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: many of the interviews was the important role of identity in feminist movement. So for the U.S.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: site, we chose activists whose work on women's issues intersects with other dimensions of

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: inequality in the U.S., like race, poverty, sexuality, disability, just to give

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: you some examples. For many of our participants, their own identities were relevant to these

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: movements, and many of them talked about their own experiences and the importance of belonging

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to different communities as part of the context and the motivation for their work. For example, Rabab Abdullahi, who helped found the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Union of Palestinian Women's Organizations, talked about her connections to Palestinian women

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: throughout the diaspora. She saw this connection as transcending national or even geographical

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: boundaries. Part of her sense of herself as belonging to this community was these transnational connections.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Another example is Kathy Cohen, whose scholarship and activism addresses queer issues within

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: communities of color. She talked about how she thinks of queer sexuality, not just in terms of

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: a straight gay binary, but as sexuality that challenges heteronormative assumptions.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So she gave an example, lesbian, gay men, bisexuals, transgender people are all marginalized

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: by their sexuality. And that's part of this LGBTQ experience and identity. But she said,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: what if we think of this category of queer as broader than that? And she gave the example

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: that in the U.S., low-income mothers who receive support from the state, which in the U.S. is called

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: temporary assistance for needy families, in the U.S., those women are similarly targeted when

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: they're affected by coercive marriage incentive policies. So for this reason, she sees them as being subordinated

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: by their sexuality and sharing some political interests with gay men and lesbians who also

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: experience their sexuality and intimate partnerships as stigmatized and prescribed.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: So she was taking this LGBTQ identity that was important to her, important to her activism, and thinking of it in a much

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: broader way. Not only is this theme of identity really important to the U.S. site, what I think

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: is really interesting is that we saw across many of these interviews that, sure, identity was

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: important to their activism, but not in this kind of simplistic terms of these people are like me,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: or these people are not like me, that often gets described as identity politics, or this kind of simplistic terms of these people are like me or these people are not like

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: me, that often gets described as identity politics or even kind of caricatured in identity politics.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Instead, many of our participants understood themselves as connected to a broad community

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: that shared political interests. And it really demonstrates their thoughtfulness about alliances across time and place and an expansive imagination about how history and social structure link people in a shared fate.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Thank you for highlighting these and your great insights. I'm sure our listeners will find these very useful.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: What would you say are one or two important things about feminist activism in the United States for people to keep in mind that are not covered in the written introductory information on the website?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Well, one thing that I think is really important is that these interviews can tell us important things

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: about how central working in coalition is to feminist activism in the U.S. And my colleague,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Zakia Luna, and I wrote a paper about this in Feminist Studies. And I want to tell you a little

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: bit about the ways we saw this playing out in our interviews. Women who belong to multiple

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: marginalized groups, like women of color, are in a position to form alliances and negotiate collaborations

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: across these different groups. And it's really been a centrally important organizing tactic

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: in the U.S. among feminist movements, and particularly for women of color, LGBTQ women,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: women who experience kind of multiple marginalized statuses. So just to give you an example,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: kind of multiple marginalized statuses. So just to give you an example, one of our interviewees,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Loretta Ross, worked for an organization called Sister Song, which was an umbrella organization for women of color and reproductive justice. And reproductive choice is a really important site in

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: U.S. feminist movement, but much of the mobilization around this topic has been around protecting

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: abortion rights. And what Loretta Ross and Sister Song said, how might considering the circumstances

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: of diverse women, you know, diverse with respect to race, class, disability, complicate this idea

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: of choice? Because certainly for those groups, access to abortion is important, but their reproductive

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: concerns also include the right to have children. And as Loretta Ross put it, to parent the children

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: that we have. She said, if you look at the foster care system, the criminal justice system,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the zero tolerance policies kicking our kids out of school. I mean, reproductive rights means a whole lot more than

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to abort or not to abort as far as we're concerned. So by broadening this definition of reproductive

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: choice to include diverse people, they were able to use this insight to help organize the March for

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Women's Lives in 2004. They said the aims of this march have to be

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: broadened beyond abortion rights to include civil rights concerns, environmental justice concerns.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And so for the very first time, they were able to bring important civil rights and environmental

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: justice organizations on board as co-sponsors of the March for Lives. So by sort of leveraging the fact that they belong to these

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: multiply marginalized groups, they were able to build a bigger and broader coalition and

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: possibly to have a much bigger impact. Some of our interviewees talked about the really intense

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: kind of work they had to do to navigate differences in cultural assumptions when they worked with groups that traditionally

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: have more power. So for example, Marta Ojeda, who was working with the Coalition for Justice and the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Maquiladoras, and she was working with a group that was across North America, but she was from

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Mexico, and those groups brought her to this larger umbrella organization. She talked about

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: working with U.S. activists who just automatically assumed

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: that the meetings would be conducted using Robert's rules of order, which is a very prescriptive

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: guide to parliamentary procedure. And so when they started the meeting, the U.S. activists

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: were just saying, okay, you get to talk. Now you get to talk. You know, invoking all this

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: complicated procedure that the Mexican activists didn't even know what

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: they were talking about. And they had to interrupt the meeting and negotiate the terms for how the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: meeting was going to work. So because of this power imbalance, some groups were coming in with

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: assumptions and kind of privileging their ways of conducting business. But I do want to end by

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: talking about how we also heard stories about how coalitions

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: could be really successful and energizing. So we talked to two representatives from Sista to Sista,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: a collective of working class, young and young adult Black and Latino women. And they talked

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: about mobilizing against the U.S. war in Iraq in coalition with other groups. And they talked about

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: how working with other groups not only gave them

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: a chance to kind of leverage their human capital to increase their turnout, but it was also an

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: opportunity for different communities of color to do political education, to learn more about each

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: other, to learn how to work together. And they saw this as important because they viewed the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: mainstream media as propagating a lot of misinformation

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: about different minority communities and that coalition was an opportunity to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: learn a different story even as they work together. So working in coalition is an important

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: theme in the U.S. women's movement. It really became an important theme when the movement first

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: had to confront the diversity that always exists within

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the category woman. And then they had to find ways to acknowledge those differences with equity and

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: fairness and in ways that could represent those different interests. And it's a challenge that

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the movement is still working on today. But I think these interviews can give us a lot of insight into

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: how those alliances work in practice.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Incredible. Thank you, Professor Cole, for joining us today.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Thank you.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Thank you for listening to this episode of Contextualizing Feminist Voices,
